Conversation:
Persuader (ER): hi, how are you?
Persuadee (EE): I'm doing well thank you
Persuader (ER): that good You knew that for every minute that passes, a child under the age of 5 dies as a result of the war in the Middle East
Persuadee (EE): That is absolutely terrible.
Persuadee (EE): Are there any good charities that are helping on this issue?
Persuader (ER): I recently read from an organization called Save a Children, which works hard to protect these children and needs financial help to continue
Persuadee (EE): How can someone help?
Persuadee (EE): I would be willing to donate my time and perhaps some money.
Persuader (ER): you can help by donating what you can, you can even help with your win in mturk, I think these children need us now
Persuadee (EE): How exactly does the money help the cause?
Persuadee (EE): What's it spent on?
Persuader (ER): is super important, help children who live the harsh reality of war, fewer and fewer people help, the money goes to the education, health and safety of these children.
Persuader (ER): how much would you be willing to donate your payment?
Persuadee (EE): I'd be willing to donate a dollar or two
Persuader (ER): eso estaria muy bien, entre todos podemos ayudar, la mayoria de los demas trabajadores  donaran todo su pago, estos ni??Â¸?Â£?os estaran agradecidos
Persuadee (EE): Perfect.
Persuadee (EE): How do I donate then?
Persuader (ER): The research team will collect all donations and send them to Save the Children, you will be deducted from your payment for this task
Summary: The conversation begins with a neutral exchange of pleasantries before quickly shifting to a serious tone as ER introduces a humanitarian issue. EE responds with concern and expresses a willingness to help, asking for ways to contribute. ER provides information about a charity and suggests donation methods, maintaining a persuasive and urgent tone. EE remains receptive and engaged, asking practical questions about the impact of donations and ultimately agreeing to contribute, indicating a collaborative and supportive sentiment.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Hello how do you feel about the Save the Children charity?
Persuadee (EE): I think it's a scam
Persuader (ER): Oh no not at all they do tons of good  is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries.
Persuadee (EE): I don't believe it.
Persuadee (EE): There is no way to prove where all those funds go.
Persuadee (EE): Plus there are starving children right here in america
Persuader (ER): This is a great organization and I am sure that they would not be allowed to continue the way they do if the money was not going where it is suppose to and every penny being accounted for.
Persuader (ER): They do so much good in the world yes there are hungry kids here but millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence.
Persuader (ER): In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence.
Persuadee (EE): That is all your opinion.
Persuadee (EE): You have no facts to back that up.
Persuader (ER): Yes part of the money does go to pay for things like advertising and all that but over 88% of the donations they recieve are sent where they are needed and that includes in the United States believe it or not.
Persuader (ER): This is according to a website that breaks down info on different charities
Persuadee (EE): Like I said those are opinions.
Persuadee (EE): There are no facts that prove that to be true.
Persuadee (EE): There are no laws that stop them from lying to people either.
Persuadee (EE): I have never meet anyone who has been aided by that organization.
Persuadee (EE): Infomercials don't impress me.
Persuader (ER): How about the fact that they have been around for over 100 years scams do not stay around that long
Persuadee (EE): Yes they do.
Persuadee (EE): Have you ever heard of evangelism?
Persuadee (EE): Again, you're only giving me an opinion.
Persuadee (EE): I just can't see any good being done.
Persuader (ER): What about the after school programs they have right here in the US or the head start programs that they offer in many rural areas?
Persuader (ER): Just because it is not happening somewhere that you see everyday does not mean that it does not exsist.
Persuader (ER): They actually fund the head start that my child will be going to till fall.
Persuader (ER): Would you be willing to atleast donate some of what you are getting paid for this study?
Persuader (ER): Right now save the children has a partnership that will double any donation made so any little bit would help
Persuadee (EE): I would not be willing to donate, because I have never seen any impact made by their organization.
Persuadee (EE): They also don't disclose their funds
Persuader (ER): oh see I think I get it now your just selfish and dont care about kids is that about right?
Persuader (ER): I mean because you personally have never seen it means it does not happen yeah totally.
Persuader (ER): Stupid
Persuadee (EE): No, I care about  kids in my community, who are in poverty.
Persuadee (EE): I have never seen this organization help them.
Summary: The conversation begins with ER expressing a positive sentiment towards a charity, while EE is skeptical and dismissive. ER attempts to persuade EE by providing information and examples of the charity's work, maintaining a positive and assertive tone. EE remains unconvinced and challenges ER's claims, expressing distrust and skepticism throughout. As the conversation progresses, ER becomes more frustrated and accusatory, while EE maintains a defensive stance, focusing on local issues and personal experience.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): How much money do you spend daily on extras like a coffee or treat?
Persuadee (EE): I spend about 5 dollars a day, you?
Persuader (ER): About 1 dollar per day.
Persuader (ER): Do you think that amount of money would make a difference in a needy child's life?
Persuadee (EE): I think it would in many places
Persuader (ER): I agree.
Persuader (ER): Are you familiar with a charity called Save the Children?
Persuadee (EE): No i am not can you explain?
Persuader (ER): Save the Children is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries.
Persuadee (EE): Wow thats great.
Persuadee (EE): How can I help?
Persuader (ER): We can help by making a donation which is essential to help ensuring children's rights to health, education, safety, etc.
Persuadee (EE): Thank you.
Persuadee (EE): How do i donate?
Persuader (ER): You can donate by choosing an amount of your task payment from $0 to all.
Persuadee (EE): Ok i will donate some
Summary: The conversation begins with a casual exchange about daily spending habits, with both participants sharing their expenses. The tone shifts as ER introduces a charitable perspective, prompting EE to consider the impact of their spending. ER employs a persuasive strategy by introducing a specific charity, Save the Children, and explaining its mission. EE expresses interest and willingness to contribute, leading to a collaborative conclusion with ER providing guidance on how to donate. The conversation evolves from casual to purposeful, with EE's engagement increasing.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Hello! How are you doing today?
Persuadee (EE): I'm doing very well thank you!
Persuadee (EE): How is your day going so far?
Persuader (ER): I am doing well.
Persuader (ER): My day has been busy visiting different places to speak about the charity I support.
Persuader (ER): Have you heard of Save the Children?
Persuadee (EE): It sounds familiar to me, could you tell me more about it?
Persuader (ER): Helping children in countries that are very war torn or in some form of conflict is what we help in.
Persuader (ER): Everyday 16,000 children die before their 5th birthday, 1 out of 80 flee the country and risk everything, and 1 out of 6 kids aren't enrolled in a school or getting education that they need
Persuadee (EE): The charity sounds like it is doing some good work in an area that badly needs it.
Persuadee (EE): Children should be our top priority all across the world.
Persuadee (EE): How can someone get involved and help out with this charity?
Persuader (ER): Oh there are quiet a few ways.
Persuader (ER): For roughly a dollar a day you can sponsor a child, you can choose a gift to spend to a child through our catalog, you could start a fundraiser, or you can just simply donate.
Persuader (ER): With that, keep in mind if you ever decide to make a monetary donation, 86% goes directly to the children, 9% fundraising, and 5% management and general.
Persuader (ER): Just so you can have an idea that we use 9 out of 10 dollars directly on the children.
Persuadee (EE): I do believe I would like to donate some money to the Save the Children charity.
Persuadee (EE): Could I pledge $1/day to start with?
Persuader (ER): absolutely thank you so much!!
Persuadee (EE): I like to donate money and time to charities that help children so I also want to thank you for educating me on this charity!
Persuader (ER): Absolutely.
Persuader (ER): I love getting the word out there on this charity.
Persuader (ER): I strongly believe in it and its values on helping children.
Persuader (ER): Children should be a priority in the world.
Persuader (ER): They are our future.
Persuadee (EE): They are our future exactly.
Persuadee (EE): Any time I can help improve a situation for a child in need I hope to be able to do so.
Persuadee (EE): How long have you been supporting this charity?
Summary: The conversation begins with a polite exchange of pleasantries before shifting to a more informative tone as ER introduces a charity they support. ER employs a persuasive strategy by sharing impactful statistics and outlining ways to contribute, while maintaining a passionate and committed sentiment. EE responds with interest and a willingness to contribute, expressing alignment with the charity's values. The conversation concludes with mutual appreciation and a shared commitment to supporting children's welfare.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Hi, how are you today?
Persuadee (EE): I am okay.
Persuadee (EE): How are you?
Persuader (ER): i'm doing great!
Persuader (ER): I'm working for Save The Children organisation, have you heard about it?
Persuadee (EE): No, I haven't.
Persuadee (EE): Can you tell me more about it?
Persuader (ER): sure.
Persuader (ER): Save the Children is an international NGO that promotes children's rights and provides relief and helps support children in developing countries
Persuadee (EE): What types of programs does it offer?
Persuader (ER): they ensure children's rights to health ,education and safety.
Persuader (ER): They are currently helping Syrian children
Persuadee (EE): On my side I don't have information about the task, only that we are trying to come up with a donation agreement.
Persuadee (EE): Are you looking for a donation for the charity?
Persuader (ER): yes, You can donate as little as 1 cent and as much as 2 dollars.
Persuader (ER): your donation will be directly deducted from your task payment
Persuadee (EE): Okay, that is good to know.
Persuadee (EE): What types of things are being done to help the children in Syria?
Persuader (ER): 1000 children were killed or injured and the donations can address these problems.
Summary: The conversation begins with a polite exchange of greetings, establishing a cordial tone. The initiator, ER, introduces their affiliation with a charitable organization, prompting curiosity from EE, who requests more information. ER provides details about the organization's mission and current efforts, maintaining an informative and persuasive tone. EE expresses interest in the donation process, and ER outlines the donation mechanism, emphasizing its impact. The conversation concludes with EE seeking further specifics on the organization's initiatives, indicating sustained interest.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Hello, how are you today.
Persuadee (EE): Very well, thank you.
Persuadee (EE): And you?
Persuader (ER): I'm great, thank you.
Persuader (ER): I'm wondering if I can have a moment of your time to talk to you about a charity program I work with?
Persuadee (EE): Sure.
Persuadee (EE): Go right ahead.
Persuader (ER): Thank you.
Persuader (ER): I'm hoping you would like to donate some of your task payment to the charity 'Save the Children', and organization that promotes children's rights and supports children in developing countries.
Persuadee (EE): I would be interested in doing do, however I must tell you I am generally very skeptical about charity orginizations in general.
Persuadee (EE): I know of many that I do not support due to the 6 figure salaries of the CEO.
Persuadee (EE): And the fact that not much of the donation actually get to the "cause".
Persuader (ER): I completely understand the skepticism due to a tenfold of shady organizations these days.
Persuader (ER): However, I can guarantee you Save the Children is a professional organization that promises their donations go to a trustable fund to support international children's causes.
Persuadee (EE): You have my attention, however this HIT is running Very long for 2 bucks already.
Persuader (ER): So can I conclude that you'd like to donate to the charity now?
Persuader (ER): Your donation will be directly deducted from your task payment.
Persuadee (EE): No, you may not draw that conclusion yet.
Persuadee (EE): I still know nothing about the charity and I\'m already a half hour into a 2 dollar HIT.
Persuadee (EE): I do not do this "only" for the money, but to try and help any way I can.
Persuadee (EE): That\'s the only reason I\'m still here.
Persuader (ER): I can understand that.
Persuader (ER): So i'd really like to thank you for your interest and time.
Persuader (ER): I can assure you if you donate as little as a penny to this charity you can be part of the solution to put an end to children's struggles from all over the world.
Persuadee (EE): I have been doing some research while waiting for your responses.
Persuadee (EE): I'll donate .50.
Summary: The conversation begins with a polite exchange of greetings, followed by ER's attempt to engage EE in a discussion about donating to a charity. EE expresses skepticism about charities, citing concerns over financial transparency. ER acknowledges these concerns and attempts to reassure EE about the legitimacy of the charity. Despite time constraints and initial reluctance, EE remains engaged and conducts independent research. Ultimately, EE decides to make a small donation, indicating a shift from skepticism to cautious participation.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Good Morning!

Persuader (ER): I'm so sorry, what a terrible thing.
Persuader (ER): Well not being short, that's fine.
Persuadee (EE): yeah, i mean, i guess
Persuader (ER): I am also here to help children in underprivileged areas, by supporting the Save the Children Charity
Persuadee (EE): what is save the children
Persuader (ER): Save the Children promotes rights and provides support for children in serious situations.
Persuader (ER): They work to get food, medical help and education to poor children in under developed countries.
Persuadee (EE): do they help lots of kids
Persuader (ER): Very much so.
Persuadee (EE): do they help kids in africa too
Persuader (ER): They absolutely do.
Persuadee (EE): do they provide medical help too though?
Persuader (ER): That's a very large part of their mission yes.
Summary: The conversation begins with a polite exchange, with ER expressing a desire for assistance and EE reciprocating with a personal concern. ER responds empathetically and shifts the focus to their involvement with a charity. EE's questions reveal a growing interest in the charity's work, while ER provides informative responses. Throughout, ER maintains a supportive and informative tone, while EE's initial personal concern transitions into curiosity about the charity's impact and reach.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Hi, how are you today?
Persuadee (EE): okay..and how are you
Persuader (ER): I'm doing great.
Persuader (ER): Out of curiousity, have you heard of the organization Save the Children?
Persuadee (EE): yes..i am very familiar..
Persuadee (EE): are you involved with charity
Persuader (ER): Yes!
Persuader (ER): I really prefer local charities but some nationwide and international ones are very dear to my heart.
Persuader (ER): Whenever we have the opportunity to donate from our task rewards I always try to give a little bit.
Persuadee (EE): me too..i see many commercials for charity on TV and it breaks my heart..
Persuadee (EE): i am also a follower of Unicef, are you familiar
Persuader (ER): Yes, I've heard of Unicef.
Persuader (ER): Another great organization.
Persuader (ER): One thing I love about Save the Children is that they have very high ratings from third-party reportings.
Persuader (ER): I know when I donate to them that my money is being used wisely!
Persuadee (EE): interesting, what do the ratings represent
Persuader (ER): The ratings are from different companies such as Better Business Bureau and American Institute of Philanthropy.
Persuader (ER): They actually get the financial reports from the IRS to confirm the accuracy in where the funds are going.
Persuadee (EE): very good...are you interested in other charities involved with children
Persuader (ER): I have given to other organizations in the past, such as World Vision, but Save the Children is really important to me right now.
Persuader (ER): There is such a lack of support right now in developing countries, and Save the Children really focuses on that.
Persuadee (EE): i happen to favor unicef since my kids collect for halloween and kids count monies as part of class project.
Persuader (ER): I totally understand that.
Persuader (ER): One thing I like about Save the Children is that it isn't just global but also focuses on kids in need here in the USA, especially the poverty-torn cities.
Persuadee (EE): i tend to give up to 100$ a month to children's org- what is your prefered donation?
Summary: The conversation begins with a polite exchange of greetings and quickly transitions into a discussion about charitable organizations. Both speakers express a shared interest in supporting children's charities, with ER showing enthusiasm for Save the Children and EE expressing a preference for Unicef. The dialogue remains friendly and informative, with ER providing detailed information about charity ratings and EE sharing personal experiences. The conversation maintains a collaborative tone, with both speakers exchanging information and personal preferences regarding charitable donations.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Hello!
Persuadee (EE): HI there!
Persuadee (EE): Are you having a good day?
Persuader (ER): Doing well!
Persuader (ER): I hope your day is the same!
Persuader (ER): So I gave been assigned the role here to get you to make a donation to the Save The Children Foundation.
Persuadee (EE): OK, i have donated to them before!!
Persuader (ER): Oh really!
Persuader (ER): That's great.
Persuader (ER): I am checking out their website and they look like a great organization.
Persuader (ER): Much of the funds donated go to help children dealing in the war torn violence of Syria.
Persuadee (EE): That sounds fantastic!
Persuadee (EE): How do I make the donation?
Persuader (ER): How much do you like to donate to the charity now?
Persuader (ER): Your donation will be directly deducted from your task payment.
Persuader (ER): You can choose any amount from $0 to all your payment.
Persuadee (EE): I would like to donate 20 cents
Persuader (ER): Great!
Persuader (ER): That's awesome.
Persuader (ER): I am going to donate as well.
Persuader (ER): We get $2.00 for this HIT so let's donate $1 each and make serious impact for children!
Persuadee (EE): I actually really need the money that I am making from this hit, so I would only like to donate 20 cents
Persuader (ER): How about $.50?
Summary: The conversation begins with a friendly exchange, establishing a positive tone. The initiator, ER, transitions to a persuasive strategy, aiming to secure a donation from EE. Initially, EE is receptive, expressing past support for the cause. However, as ER suggests a higher donation, EE reveals a personal financial constraint, maintaining a polite but firm stance. ER attempts to negotiate a compromise, showing persistence in their persuasive efforts while respecting EE's situation.

Conversation:
Persuader (ER): Have you heard of the Save the Children non profit organization?
Persuadee (EE): Hello, yes I have but I am not sure what the charity works towards
Persuader (ER): It is an international non-governmental organization that promotes children's rights, provides relief and helps support children in developing countries.
Persuadee (EE): Ah ok very nice.
Persuadee (EE): It sounds like a good charity.
Persuadee (EE): Are you thinking of donating to it?
Persuader (ER): I am thinking about it.
Persuader (ER): I was hoping you would think about it too.
Persuader (ER): It just sucks that millions of Syrian children have grown up facing the daily threat of violence.
Persuader (ER): In the first two months of 2018 alone, 1,000 children were reportedly killed or injured in intensifying violence.
Persuader (ER): This makes me angry and was wondering if it did the same for you?
Persuadee (EE): Yes, I definitely understand you.
Persuadee (EE): It is very difficult to see on the news what is happening in Syria and the violence and terrorism that is going on in the country
Persuader (ER): I know it is crazy.
Persuader (ER): Sometimes I think about the little things I buy.
Persuader (ER): Like yesterday I had a craving for candy so I bought a bag of smarties for $2.79.
Persuader (ER): Sometimes I wonder how much it could help someone else instead of just satisfying my cravings.
Persuadee (EE): Yes that is very true.
Persuadee (EE): I usually donate $1.00 or $2.00 at restaurants or stores whenever they ask me if I would like to donate.
Persuadee (EE): I think it is the least I could do.
Persuader (ER): That is nice.
Persuader (ER): I try to do the same if I have the extra money.
Persuader (ER): Usually it is not something I am a strong believer in though.
Persuader (ER): I really like helping others that in third world countries that have no idea what wealth is.
Persuadee (EE): Yes I understand.
Persuadee (EE): I have been to third world countries in South America and seeing the living conditions of some people is very tough.
Persuadee (EE): The poverty there is a lot higher than what we are used to seeing and it can be shocking.
Persuader (ER): I have only been to Mexico and that was an eye opener.
Persuader (ER): One dollar is so valuable to them.
Persuader (ER): It is crazy!
Persuadee (EE): Yes I know.
Persuadee (EE): Any amount of money can help.
Persuadee (EE): I think that we take many things for granted such as running water, and always having food on the table.
Persuader (ER): Right!
Summary: The conversation begins with ER introducing a nonprofit organization, aiming to inform EE and evoke a shared concern for global issues. As the discussion progresses, ER employs emotional appeals and personal reflections to emphasize the impact of donations, while EE responds with understanding and shares personal experiences. Both speakers express empathy and a sense of responsibility, gradually aligning their sentiments towards the importance of charitable actions, highlighting a mutual recognition of privilege and the value of small contributions.

ER maintains a persuasive tone, emphasizing the organization's comprehensive impact and aligning with EE's values. EE's interest grows, leading to a direct inquiry about how to contribute, to which ER responds with encouragement for donations.

Persuader (ER): Donate to Save the Children, please.
Persuader (ER): Think about those poor kids.
Persuadee (EE): Well tell me a little bit more about the charity.
Persuader (ER): It's really all in the name.
Persuader (ER): You have a moral responsibility.
Persuadee (EE): A lot of charities are just a name and they don't do what they promise.
Persuadee (EE): How do I know my money will go where it supposed to?
Persuader (ER): They're a world-famous trustworthy charity.
Persuader (ER): If they were fraudulent or misallocating funds, surely there'd have been a scandal.
Persuadee (EE): Ok.
Persuadee (EE): So why do they deserve my money as opposed to other charities like St Judes or the Red Cross>
Persuader (ER): Of course you can donate to other charities.
Persuader (ER): It's not necessarily a zero-sum game.
Persuader (ER): I can tell you, however, that Save the Children is, in a way, more immediate in helping people (as opposed to fighting disease like St Jude's) and delivers services similar to the Red Cross, but directed toward children.
Persuader (ER): So, please: think of the children!
Persuadee (EE): Do they help kids in the US?
Persuadee (EE): I like to help people that are close to home.
Persuader (ER): Their assistance is directed toward children in developing countries, where, unlike most of the US, children are totally deprived of opportunity and basic services.
Persuader (ER): Though you, being the generous person you are, like helping those at home, is there a reason not to help children abroad?
Persuadee (EE): I don't mind helping those abroad.
Persuadee (EE): But there are a lot kids here in the US who deal with poverty.
Persuadee (EE): So it's not that I don't care about the children elsewhere, just want to help those at home first.
Summary: The conversation begins with ER's emotional appeal for donations, emphasizing moral responsibility. EE responds with skepticism, questioning the charity's credibility and effectiveness. ER reassures EE by highlighting the charity's reputation and addressing concerns about fund allocation. As the conversation progresses, EE shifts focus to prioritizing local aid, while ER attempts to broaden EE's perspective on global needs. ER maintains a persuasive stance, while EE remains considerate but firm in their preference for supporting local causes.

Persuader (ER): Good afternoon.

Persuadee (EE): That's incredible.
Persuadee (EE): I wasn't aware that they did all of that.

Persuader (ER): I imagine they'll help there if they aren't stretched too thin.
Persuadee (EE): So save the children is a worldwide organization it sounds like!
Persuader (ER): It is!
Persuader (ER): Do you ever donate to organizations like this?
Persuader (ER): My brother, sister, and I replaced birthday gifts with charity donations a few years ago.
Persuader (ER): It saved on clutter and felt great to give to charities.
Persuadee (EE): I've given to a few charities before, but never this one.
Persuadee (EE): I'm always so skeptical of charities to be honest.
Persuader (ER): Same here.
Persuader (ER): I remember reading about some questionable charities following hurricanes in Haiti and Puerto Rico.
Persuader (ER): It's a bummer when that money gets siphoned off.
Persuader (ER): I just looked up Save the Children on Charity Navigator and they give the org an 88.3 rating out of 100 including a 97 for transparency.
Persuadee (EE): Wow that's a really great rating!
Persuadee (EE): I think money that goes to kids is a super important cause.
Persuader (ER): I plan on giving my payment for this exercise to Save the Children based on my research.
Persuader (ER): Would you like to donate to the charity as well?
Persuader (ER): After we are done chatting, I think you can tell them the amount you want donated.
Summary: The conversation begins with a casual exchange before ER introduces the topic of a charity, Save the Children, which they have been reading about. ER shares information about the charity's work, prompting EE's interest and surprise. As the discussion progresses, both express skepticism about charities due to past experiences but acknowledge the importance of transparency and effectiveness. ER provides credibility to the charity with a high rating, leading to a positive sentiment towards donating, with ER planning to donate and inviting EE to consider doing the same.

Persuadee (EE): It's great to hear there are people out there doing such important work.
Persuadee (EE): Have you ever donated to them?
Persuader (ER): Yes I have , how much do you spend on unnecessary stuff like a bag of snack or candy.
Persuader (ER): You Know small donations can help a lot of children and their families

Persuadee (EE): I suppose even with the economy being as hard as it is, exchange rates are still good enough to make a real impact.
Persuader (ER): Yes any donations made to helpless children make a real impact on their life.
Persuader (ER): Not many kids get a real shot and they all deserve one If I had a chance to change a childs life foe the better and didn't I would not be able to live with myself.
Persuadee (EE): That's a good point, I think a lot of the times the little things we can do that have really positive impacts kind of get lost in the shuffle.

Persuadee (EE): So how did you decide what was right for you?
Persuader (ER): I gave what was given to me .
Persuader (ER): Over the next few chats I'm going to tell you the story of Bruce a child that like alot of these chidren need help but threw Save The Chidren found it.
Persuader (ER): At the end Of our next few chats I'm going to ask you to  donate what you earn from this survey .
Persuader (ER): I want you to think about what it means to save a child thats in trouble and how by saving that child you find new hope in your own life.
Persuadee (EE): I'm certainly willing to listen.
Persuadee (EE): Tell me about Bruce.
Persuader (ER): Bruce was born to a single mother who was only 14 at the time he came into this world , the girls mother and father were ashamed of her pregnancy and kicked out of the house.
Persuader (ER): The founder of save the children heard about the family and learned of Bruces story .
Persuader (ER): He came to meet Bruce .
Persuadee (EE): That poor girl, being rejected by her own family like that.
Persuadee (EE): I'm glad that Bruce was taken in, though.
Persuadee (EE): How did the visit go?

ER reassures EE about fund usage, prompting EE to inquire about transparency and ratings. As ER shares personal experiences and the impact of donations, EE becomes more receptive and curious about ER's motivations. ER plans to share a specific story to further engage EE, who is now open to listening and learning more about the organization's impact.

Persuader (ER): Hello, have you heard of Save The Children?
Persuadee (EE): I think so, it sounds familiar.
Persuadee (EE): it is a nonprofit charity if i recall.
Persuadee (EE): What exactly do they do?
Persuader (ER): Save The Children helps kids from around the world by taking contributions from generous patrons. Kids from countries that have been stricken by poverty, violence, and other blights.
Persuadee (EE): What countries has the charity worked in recently?
Persuader (ER): Well, we have programs set up in 120 countries in total right now.
Persuader (ER): Some of our most recent campaigns involve Myanmar - in Rohingya where parents and their children have been forced to flee because of violence to surrounding countries. In the largest refugee camp stationed in Bangladesh, there are an estimated 915,000 children and adults taking shelter.
Persuadee (EE): Wow that sounds like a really robust program.
Persuadee (EE): How long has Save the Children been around?
Persuader (ER): It was founded in 1919, on April 15th in London - UK.
Persuadee (EE): Do you work for Save the Children or do you just volunteer for the charity?
Persuader (ER): I do not work for them, I work on behalf of them.
Persuader (ER): That is why I'm talking to you today.
Persuader (ER): These children need help, and could use it from generous people like you.
Persuader (ER): A meal, an education, an opportunity like everyone else, that is all these kids want.
Persuader (ER): Even one cent will add up to help a child in need, but if you wish you may donate up to 2 dollars.
Persuader (ER): For every cent you donate it will come directly from your task payment.
Persuadee (EE): I love to help charities that serve a good cause and I would love to donate but I do have one question.
Persuadee (EE): What is the portion of donations that goes to children versus the portion that goes to administration or other expenses
Persuader (ER): Sure, absolutely. In 2017, 86% went to Program services - or services that directly help aid these children. 9% went towards fundraising efforts, and 5% went towards our Management & other general costs. In 2018 we anticipate similar numbers.
Persuadee (EE): That's pretty impressive!
Persuadee (EE): Not too many charities can claim such a strong commitment to the cause.
Persuader (ER): We do it for them, not for ourselves.
Persuader (ER): And we hope our numbers reflect that amount of love and effort that goes toward what we do.
Persuadee (EE): I'd be willing to donate $1 to Save the Children.
Summary: The conversation begins with ER introducing Save The Children and explaining its mission, while EE shows curiosity and asks for more details. ER provides information about the charity's operations and recent efforts, gradually building a case for support. EE expresses admiration for the charity's work and inquires about the allocation of donations, showing a thoughtful approach to giving. ER reassures EE with transparency about financials, leading to EE's willingness to contribute, reflecting a successful persuasive effort by ER.

Persuadee (EE): That is very impressive.
Persuadee (EE): Do you know on average how much money the charity makes per year?

Persuadee (EE): That way nobody can question anything.

Persuader (ER): When I first heard about these super well known organizations only actually using about 5% of their proceeds for their services I was shocked.
Persuader (ER): Save the Children uses a total of 86% of proceeds for their services and programs!
Persuader (ER): The rest goes to "fundraising, management, and general" as the website says.

ER employs a strategy of providing detailed information and statistics to build credibility and highlight the charity's transparency and impact.
